awd_titl_txt: Scaling Elements of a Competency-Based Hybrid Instructional Model into Advanced Manufacturing Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
A nationwide shortage of qualified manufacturing technicians and the demand for training that keeps pace with rapidly changing technology has driven collaboration between education and industry partners. To fill the need for qualified manufacturing technicians, Northwest State Community College (NSCC) will work with industries to improve a competency-based advanced manufacturing program and promote its broader adoption. NSCC plans wide-spread implementation of its instructional model through a Networked Improvement Community (NIC) of partner colleges and their local industries across four states: Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, and North Carolina. Through mentorship, professional development, and focused cooperation, this project will improve the effectiveness of advanced manufacturing courses, increase access to technical education programs, and prepare technicians with the skillsets that employers require. On a broad scale, this project will promote diversity by increasing opportunities for underserved populations to pursue high-demand, family-sustaining occupations in the technical workforce.

The goals of this project are to: provide a more accessible method of instruction, remove barriers for existing and potential college students, align students' skills attainment with workplace demands, and increase the knowledge of implementing a competency-based hybrid instructional model for advanced manufacturing courses. NSCC will demonstrate the process of converting two traditional courses to the new model, and partner colleges in the NIC will determine which elements of the model are best suited to adapt within their programs. NSCC will then work with the partners to incorporate the model into specific courses. In addition, NSCC will administer nine, two-day professional development workshops for technical faculty from additional colleges in the state-wide networks of the NIC partners, with the potential to impact ninety colleges. NSCC will continue to mentor faculty on scaling elements of the model into programs at their institutions and will provide assistance with implementation efforts.

This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Scaling Elements of a Competency-based/Hybrid Instructional Model into Advanced Manufacturing Courses

Project PI: Thomas Wylie

Federal Award ID: 1902225

 

In 2019, Northwest State Community College received a $500,005 NSF ATE grant to scale and replicate their successful competency-based/hybrid instructional model for Advanced Manufacturing courses to other colleges throughout the country, through faculty professional development and mentoring.  This instructional model focuses on developing and assessing the technical skills of students to better prepare them to work as a manufacturing technician in an industrial environment, by moving the lecture online which allows for more time to be devoted to hands-on learning.   NSCC has successfully converted over 20 technical courses to this new model over the past 8 years.  This project focuses on instructing college faculty on how to implement one or more elements of this model into their curriculum to improve the effectiveness and student access for their courses.  Figure 1 shows a list of the various competency-based/hybrid model elements (outside the circle). 

Faculty Professional Development:

Faculty professional development consisted of individual or group sessions that varied in length, with a focus on how to improve the effectiveness or the student access to one or more of their technical courses.  140 college faculty members from 48 unique 2-year and 4-year colleges in 7 states were trained/mentored through this project over a 4 year period.  52% of these faculty have implemented a competency-based/hybrid element into at least one of their college courses.  Some examples of curricular changes included: faculty implemented open education resource materials into their courses, replacing expensive textbooks, some created their own videos on how to run technical lab equipment, while others chose to assess the hands-on skills of students.  Faculty who decided to implement a change were also mentored by this project to assure they had adequate resources and support.  These curriculum changes the college faculty made had a positive impact on 1,075 college students across the country, in the Fall 2023 semester. 

 

Converting Courses:

Two technical courses at NSCC were also converted to the competency-based hybrid model, Instrumentation & Controls and Electrical Troubleshooting.  Faculty were part of the conversion process and learned how to create all learning objects for the Sakai LMS.  This also creates a larger body of work that will be available to other college faculty.  Assessments, simulations, lab exercises, videos, and PPT/PDF documents were created in this process and will be available to the public through ATE Central website.  The project PI not only instructed at least 10 faculty on how to convert a traditional lecture/lab course to a competency based/hybrid delivery, but also created a document that will assist faculty on how to perform the conversion process.  This process uses a reverse design approach, which is shown in Figure 2.   The most critical part of this process is the alignment of the curriculum to the industry needs.  

Improving Student Access: 

This project helped colleges provide increased access to technical curriculum for all types of students.  The project taught faculty how to move their lecture online with active learning objects (e.g. videos, podcasts, and simulations), and how to create a flexible, scheduled and open lab model.  The pandemic created a new level of access the project had to assist college faculty with, which was remote learning with virtual computers.  This allowed students to access software and learning simulations from home (24/7) using their own computer with an internet browser.  Prior to this students had to travel to the college to get access to this technology.  A number of colleges implemented this technology into their courses.  This technology is still used after the pandemic and is a great tool for effective and accelerated student learning.  Figure 3 shows an example of a simulator used in a virtual computer.  Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) are systems that control industrial machinery and are a very common 2-year college Engineering Technology departments.  The hardware simulator is the one found in the technical lab at the college for hands-on training.  The virtual simulator is found in the virtual computer, and will function the same as the hardware simulator, so the students can do their lab exercises from home instead of on campus.  Virtual simulations are very effective methods of learning, but do not replace the effectiveness of hands-on learning.

 

 

 

Summary:

This project has advanced the knowledge of a large group of technical faculty on how to modify their curriculum to be more relevant, effective and accessible to students, using current technology and innovative techniques.


 




 


 

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2024
Modified by: Thomas W Wylie

Project Outcomes Report


Award Title: Scaling Elements of a Competency-based/Hybrid Instructional Model into Advanced Manufacturing Courses


Project PI: Thomas Wylie


Federal Award ID: 1902225





In 2019, Northwest State Community College received a $500,005 NSF ATE grant to scale and replicate their successful competency-based/hybrid instructional model for Advanced Manufacturing courses to other colleges throughout the country, through faculty professional development and mentoring. This instructional model focuses on developing and assessing the technical skills of students to better prepare them to work as a manufacturing technician in an industrial environment, by moving the lecture online which allows for more time to be devoted to hands-on learning.  NSCC has successfully converted over 20 technical courses to this new model over the past 8 years. This project focuses on instructing college faculty on how to implement one or more elements of this model into their curriculum to improve the effectiveness and student access for their courses. Figure 1 shows a list of the various competency-based/hybrid model elements (outside the circle).


 


Faculty Professional Development:


Faculty professional development consisted of individual or group sessions that varied in length, with a focus on how to improve the effectiveness or the student access to one or more of their technical courses. 140 college faculty members from 48 unique 2-year and 4-year colleges in 7 states were trained/mentored through this project over a 4 year period. 52% of these faculty have implemented a competency-based/hybrid element into at least one of their college courses. Some examples of curricular changes included: faculty implemented open education resource materials into their courses, replacing expensive textbooks, some created their own videos on how to run technical lab equipment, while others chose to assess the hands-on skills of students. Faculty who decided to implement a change were also mentored by this project to assure they had adequate resources and support. These curriculum changes the college faculty made had a positive impact on 1,075 college students across the country, in the Fall 2023 semester.





Converting Courses:


Two technical courses at NSCC were also converted to the competency-based hybrid model, Instrumentation & Controls and Electrical Troubleshooting. Faculty were part of the conversion process and learned how to create all learning objects for the Sakai LMS. This also creates a larger body of work that will be available to other college faculty. Assessments, simulations, lab exercises, videos, and PPT/PDF documents were created in this process and will be available to the public through ATE Central website. The project PI not only instructed at least 10 faculty on how to convert a traditional lecture/lab course to a competency based/hybrid delivery, but also created a document that will assist faculty on how to perform the conversion process. This process uses a reverse design approach, which is shown in Figure 2.  The most critical part of this process is the alignment of the curriculum to the industry needs.


 


Improving Student Access:


This project helped colleges provide increased access to technical curriculum for all types of students. The project taught faculty how to move their lecture online with active learning objects (e.g. videos, podcasts, and simulations), and how to create a flexible, scheduled and open lab model. The pandemic created a new level of access the project had to assist college faculty with, which was remote learning with virtual computers. This allowed students to access software and learning simulations from home (24/7) using their own computer with an internet browser. Prior to this students had to travel to the college to get access to this technology. A number of colleges implemented this technology into their courses. This technology is still used after the pandemic and is a great tool for effective and accelerated student learning. Figure 3 shows an example of a simulator used in a virtual computer. Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) are systems that control industrial machinery and are a very common 2-year college Engineering Technology departments. The hardware simulator is the one found in the technical lab at the college for hands-on training. The virtual simulator is found in the virtual computer, and will function the same as the hardware simulator, so the students can do their lab exercises from home instead of on campus. Virtual simulations are very effective methods of learning, but do not replace the effectiveness of hands-on learning.











 


Summary:


This project has advanced the knowledge of a large group of technical faculty on how to modify their curriculum to be more relevant, effective and accessible to students, using current technology and innovative techniques.
